intro: Patagonium leucopogon, commonly known as the white-tipped cushion plant, is a flowering plant native to the southern Andes of South America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is adapted to high-altitude, cold environments. The plant forms dense, low-growing cushions with small, leathery leaves that help reduce water loss in harsh conditions. Its flowers are typically white or pale pink, with five petals, and bloom in late spring or early summer. Patagonium leucopogon plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for alpine wildlife.
